ground_truth_caption: This image shows a dermatologist discussing various skin conditions with a patient. The patient has a skin disease that appears as large, white, cicatricial patches on the skin, mainly located on the nose. The dermatologist considers various options for the diagnosis, including actinic keratosis, lichen sclerosus, granulomatous inflammation, sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, lymphoma, and demodex. The dermatologist also mentions that the patient has good health and there are no comedonal eye openings, which is a clue that it may not be lichen sclerosus. The treatment options for this skin disease include topical treatments and, in some cases, surgery.

ground_truth_caption: This image describes the clinical presentation of MF in children, which can be misleading and cause delays in diagnosis. It presents as patches and plaque on unexposed areas such as the breast, lower abdomen, and buttocks, but in 45% of cases, it appears as whitish, hypopigmented lesions.
